Speech-to-Text Conversion
Techniques, Tools, and Trade-offs
Omkar Ninav
June 30, 2025

Good [morning/afternoon], thank you for taking the time to attend this presentation.
The goal today is to give a structured and technical overview of speech-to-text conversion ‚Äî how it works, what tools and models are currently leading the field, and what trade-offs are involved in choosing a particular solution.
This is a technology that‚Äôs become foundational in a wide range of domains ‚Äî from customer support and assistive tech, to real-time captioning and voice interfaces. I‚Äôll be focusing on how Python-based tools like Whisper, Wav2Vec2, and others can be used to build robust STT systems.
By the end, I hope to outline clearly: - How the core pipeline functions, - Which models are best suited for various use cases, and - What the cost and accuracy implications are ‚Äî especially in terms of practical deployment.
Let‚Äôs begin with the basics.

What is Speech-to-Text?

Converts spoken language into written text
Also known as Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR)
Used in applications like:

Virtual assistants (e.g., Siri, Alexa)
Captioning & subtitling
Meeting transcription
Voice commands



Speech-to-text, also called Automatic Speech Recognition or ASR, is the process of converting human speech into readable, written text.
At a high level, it‚Äôs the core technology behind systems like Siri, Alexa, Google Assistant, and any app that takes voice input.
Beyond virtual assistants, it‚Äôs widely used in live captioning, automated meeting transcription, voice commands in smart devices, and even accessibility tools for people with disabilities.
In recent years, thanks to deep learning and advances in compute power, STT systems have become far more accurate and accessible ‚Äî even for developers like us working with open-source tools.
In the next slide, I‚Äôll walk through the high-level architecture of how speech-to-text systems are typically designed.

How Speech-to-Text Works

Audio Input
Voice signal captured from a microphone or file
Feature Extraction
Converts raw audio into numerical features (e.g., MFCCs, spectrograms)
Acoustic Model
Maps features to phonemes or characters using ML/DL models
Language Model
Predicts word sequences for context-aware transcription
Decoder
Aligns acoustic and language models to produce final text






flowchart LR
  A[Audio Input<br/>Voice signal] --> B[Feature Extraction<br/>MFCCs / Spectrograms]
  B --> C[Acoustic Model<br/>ML/DL-based]
  C --> D[Language Model<br/>Contextual Prediction]
  D --> E[Decoder<br/>Final Text Output]







This slide breaks down the standard architecture behind most modern speech-to-text systems.
It starts with the audio input, typically a microphone recording or audio file, which is passed to a feature extraction module. This module transforms the raw waveform into meaningful patterns ‚Äî usually through methods like MFCCs (Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients) or spectrograms.
Next, the acoustic model interprets these features and maps them to likely phonemes or character sequences. Traditionally, these were HMM-based, but today they‚Äôre often deep neural networks like CNNs, RNNs, or transformers.
The language model plays a critical role ‚Äî it uses linguistic context to predict the most likely word sequences. This is what helps the system understand the difference between similar-sounding phrases like ‚Äúice cream‚Äù vs ‚ÄúI scream.‚Äù
Finally, the decoder combines all of this ‚Äî the acoustic predictions and the language probabilities ‚Äî to produce the final transcription.
Understanding this pipeline helps clarify where different models and libraries fit in, and what we can tweak based on accuracy, speed, or deployment constraints.

Techniques: Traditional ASR

HMMs + GMMs
Early models for mapping acoustic features to phonemes
n-gram Language Models
Predict word sequences based on prior word probabilities
Feature Extraction (MFCCs)
Converts raw audio into spectral features


Let‚Äôs start with traditional ASR systems.
Early speech recognition was built using Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMMs). HMMs model the sequential nature of speech, and GMMs handle the probability distributions of acoustic features within each state.
For predicting the next word or phrase, systems used n-gram language models ‚Äî for example, a trigram model would look at the two previous words to estimate the next one. These models were easy to implement but had limited ability to understand context or long-term dependencies.
The front end of these systems used MFCCs (Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients) to convert audio waveforms into feature vectors that captured the shape and tone of the speech signal. MFCCs remain popular even in some deep learning systems due to their compact and informative representation of sound.
While these traditional methods laid the foundation for modern ASR, they struggled with complex variations like accents, overlapping speakers, and noisy environments.

Techniques: Deep Learning & Modern Trends

RNNs, CNNs, Transformers
Deep models for sequence modeling and attention
End-to-End Models (CTC / Attention)
Learn transcription directly from audio input
Trends

Self-supervised learning (e.g.¬†Wav2Vec 2.0)
Multilingual support (e.g.¬†Whisper)
On-device inference (edge devices, mobile)



Modern speech recognition systems have shifted toward deep learning.
Initially, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) were used because they could model sequences ‚Äî perfect for speech. Then came Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to handle time-frequency patterns in audio. Today, transformers are dominant due to their superior performance in modeling long-range dependencies and context.
Instead of breaking the process into multiple modules like traditional ASR, deep learning systems often use end-to-end models. These can be trained to map directly from raw audio to text using techniques like Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) or attention-based models.
Recent trends in STT are pushing the field even further: - Self-supervised learning enables models like Wav2Vec 2.0 to learn from raw, unlabeled audio ‚Äî drastically reducing the need for costly transcriptions. - Models like Whisper offer multilingual support and are robust to accents and background noise. - There‚Äôs also growing interest in on-device inference, where models are small and efficient enough to run on phones, edge devices, or embedded systems ‚Äî ensuring both privacy and speed.
These modern techniques make STT more accurate, scalable, and accessible than ever before.

Python Libraries for Speech-to-Text (1/2)

Whisper (OpenAI)

Transformer-based, multilingual
High accuracy, runs offline

SpeechRecognition

Simple API wrapper for Google, IBM, etc.
Easy for beginners

Wav2Vec 2.0 (Hugging Face)

Pretrained self-supervised models
High-quality transcriptions



This slide introduces three powerful Python tools used in speech-to-text development.
Whisper is one of the best-performing open-source models available. It supports multilingual audio, works offline, and is robust to noise and accents. It does require a decent GPU, but the results are exceptional.
SpeechRecognition is simple and wraps around cloud APIs like Google or IBM Watson. It‚Äôs great for quick demos or for beginners but is not suitable for offline or secure environments.
Wav2Vec 2.0 is built by Meta and available on Hugging Face. It‚Äôs transformer-based, pre-trained on massive audio corpora, and can deliver near state-of-the-art accuracy, especially on clean English audio.

Python Libraries for Speech-to-Text (2/2)

DeepSpeech (Mozilla)

Lightweight and fast
Less accurate on noisy inputs

Kaldi (via PyKaldi)

Research-grade toolkit
Steeper learning curve

Vosk

Real-time offline STT
Works on Raspberry Pi, Android, desktops
Multilingual, very lightweight



DeepSpeech, from Mozilla, was designed for simplicity and edge deployment. It‚Äôs fast and easy to install, but less accurate in noisy or real-world conditions compared to newer models.
Kaldi is a highly flexible and powerful toolkit often used in academia or enterprise. It offers full control over the speech recognition pipeline, including acoustic and language models. However, it‚Äôs not beginner-friendly and requires significant setup effort. The Python wrapper PyKaldi helps but still demands technical depth.
Vosk is an often-overlooked gem. It supports real-time offline transcription in 20+ languages, including Hindi, Marathi, and more. It runs even on low-resource devices like Raspberry Pi or Android phones. It‚Äôs ideal for small, local deployments where Whisper would be too heavy or cloud is not an option.
Splitting the content across two slides avoids overcrowding and gives us room to discuss each tool more clearly.

This table summarizes the strengths and limitations of some of the most widely used speech-to-text models and toolkits.
Starting with Whisper, it stands out as a balanced option ‚Äî it offers high accuracy, works offline, supports multiple languages, and is open-source. It does require a decent GPU to run efficiently, especially for long audio files or real-time use, but it‚Äôs very accessible for developers and teams with modest resources.
Wav2Vec 2.0 is another excellent option. It provides high accuracy, especially when fine-tuned on domain-specific data. However, it‚Äôs primarily trained on English datasets, so multilingual support is more limited unless you retrain it. It‚Äôs open-source and can be accessed via Hugging Face.
Google Speech-to-Text API is a commercial solution. It offers very high accuracy and supports over 100 languages. It‚Äôs excellent for real-time use cases and scales easily. However, it‚Äôs not free ‚Äî the cost is around $1.44 per hour, and it requires internet connectivity, which may raise privacy concerns in sensitive environments.
DeepSpeech was designed to be lightweight and fast, making it suitable for edge devices. That said, it has started to lag behind in terms of accuracy, especially on noisy or accented inputs, and its development has slowed down in recent years.
Kaldi is extremely powerful and flexible. It‚Äôs used in many academic and enterprise applications where low-level control is needed ‚Äî for instance, custom language models, speaker adaptation, and complex pipelines. However, it‚Äôs not beginner-friendly, and the learning curve is steep. PyKaldi can help if you want to work with it in Python.
Vosk is surprisingly effective given its small size. It offers decent accuracy, real-time performance, works fully offline, and is extremely easy to integrate ‚Äî especially on embedded systems or mobile platforms.For projects targeting Indian languages or edge devices, Vosk can be a better fit than Whisper or cloud APIs.
This slide helps us decide which model might be most appropriate depending on our project constraints ‚Äî whether we prioritize cost, offline access, multilingual support, or ease of use.
In the next slide, we‚Äôll break down the cost aspect more specifically, including free tiers and usage pricing for cloud APIs.

All of these models are completely free and can run offline. This gives us full control over the transcription pipeline, which is useful for privacy-sensitive environments or when working with large amounts of audio data.
Whisper is the most accurate among these and works well out of the box. Wav2Vec 2.0 is also strong, especially with fine-tuning. DeepSpeech is lightweight but older, and Kaldi offers research-grade customization ‚Äî though with a steep learning curve. Vosk, in particular, is very lightweight. It can run on mobile devices and Raspberry Pi, making it ideal for resource-constrained environments.
The key point here is: these tools have no recurring costs and no internet dependency ‚Äî ideal for secure or offline environments.

Cloud APIs offer high performance and easy integration, but they come at a cost.
These services typically charge around $1.44 to $1.60 per hour of audio processed. The pricing is usually pay-as-you-go, and may include limited free tiers initially.
They are useful for real-time transcription, multi-language support, and when we don‚Äôt want to manage infrastructure ourselves.
However, they require internet access, and data is transmitted to external servers, which might raise privacy or compliance concerns.
So while cloud APIs are powerful, we need to carefully evaluate whether the convenience justifies the ongoing cost and cloud dependency.

Cost ‚Äì Summary & Recommendation

Open-Source Models (Whisper, Wav2Vec, etc.)

‚úÖ Free and offline
‚ö†Ô∏è Require setup and local resources

Cloud APIs (Google, AWS, Azure)

‚úÖ Easy to use, scalable
‚ö†Ô∏è Ongoing cost and privacy trade-offs


‚úîÔ∏è Recommendation:
Use Whisper or Wav2Vec 2.0 for local, cost-effective transcription
Use Vosk for light, multilingual offline STT (e.g.¬†edge devices)
Use Cloud APIs only for real-time or highly multilingual needs

To summarize, open-source models like Whisper and Wav2Vec are ideal when we want a free, offline, and private solution. They do require more local compute and some initial setup, but the cost savings and control can be significant ‚Äî especially for batch processing or secure applications.
Cloud APIs are best suited when we need real-time transcription, scalability, or support for multiple languages out of the box. However, they incur ongoing costs and may raise data privacy issues.
For most internal use cases or offline processing, Whisper offers the best trade-off. For external client-facing products, cloud APIs can be considered with proper cost tracking.

‚úÖ Final Decision
Chosen Model: openai/whisper-medium
üîπ Why Whisper Medium?

‚úÖ Good balance between accuracy and inference speed
‚úÖ Lower VRAM & compute requirements than large models
‚úÖ Suitable for local deployment (runs on RTX 4050)
‚úÖ Consistent performance across test cases
‚úÖ Robust to mild accents and moderate background noise

üî∏ Not Chosen:

whisper-large: Higher accuracy but heavier (more VRAM)
whisper-tiny / base: Faster, but less accurate


After testing several models, we‚Äôve decided to go with Whisper Medium.
It provides a strong balance between accuracy and speed, especially on a GPU like RTX 4050. While the large model performed slightly better in accuracy, its inference time and GPU memory use were significantly higher ‚Äî which isn‚Äôt ideal for our production use.
The tiny and base models were faster, but dropped too much in transcription quality, especially for longer or more technical audio.
Whisper Medium gives us consistent results and can run fully offline, which fits both our deployment and privacy goals. It‚Äôs the best fit given our constraints and performance requirements.

üìù Transcript Evaluation ‚Äì Whisper vs Original
üéôÔ∏è Sample: NPTEL Lecture ‚Äì Literature History
üìå Original:
> At the outset, this being the first session, it is very important to give an overview of the course. This course is spread over 12 weeks and we may have 30 hours of teaching involved in this. Let me also introduce you to the objectives of this course so that the intentions become clearer.
üåÄ Whisper Output:
> At the outset, this being the first session, it is very important to give an overview of the course. This course is spread over 12 weeks and we may have 30 hours of teaching involved in this and we also introduce you to the objectives of this course so that the intentions become more clear.
üîπ ‚úÖ Core content retained
üîπ ‚ö†Ô∏è Minor stylistic variation ‚Äì rephrasing & joined sentences

üß† Observation Summary

Whisper captured all key points with high fidelity
Punctuation differences due to lack of postprocessing
Filler words (‚Äúwe also‚Äù) inserted naturally from speech
Ideal for lecture summarization, accessibility, or note generation


In this real-world evaluation using an NPTEL lecture, Whisper accurately transcribed complex academic content, maintaining meaning and structure.
The differences observed are stylistic, not factual. Punctuation is less formal, and there‚Äôs a natural flow of spoken language like ‚Äúwe also introduce‚Ä¶‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúLet me also introduce‚Ä¶‚Äù
This shows that Whisper is reliable for lecture or classroom transcription, even in moderately accented or Indian English speech. It preserves intent and phrasing even with unedited audio input.

üìä Whisper Accuracy
üîπ Quantitative Evaluation

Semantic Similarity (cosine): 0.9766 ‚úÖ
ROUGE-1 F1 Score: 0.9714

ROUGE-L F1 Score: 0.9524

Word Error Rate (WER): 12.43%

üîç Interpretation

‚úÖ Very high semantic match ‚Äì meaning fully preserved

‚úÖ Low WER ‚Äì minor word-level issues

‚úÖ ROUGE scores confirm strong overlap in phrase structure

‚ö†Ô∏è Differences mostly in punctuation, filler words, and phrasing


In this test, Whisper Medium showed outstanding performance on an NPTEL academic lecture.
A semantic similarity score of 0.9766 indicates that the transcript preserves nearly all the original meaning. ROUGE-1 and ROUGE-L scores also reflect strong overlap in vocabulary and sentence structure.
The Word Error Rate is just 12.43%, which is excellent for real-world speech and unedited audio.
Whisper handled Indian English fluently, captured the instructional tone well, and only struggled with minor phrasing and punctuation.
This confirms Whisper‚Äôs suitability for academic transcription, content indexing, and lecture summarization tasks.

üìù Transcript Comparison ‚Äì Whisper vs Original
üéôÔ∏è Sample: NPTEL Lecture ‚Äì Taylor Series Intro
üìå Original:
> Welcome back to the lectures on Engineering Mathematics-I.
> Today, we will learn Taylor‚Äôs Polynomial and Taylor Series.
üåÄ Whisper Output:
> Hi, welcome back to the lectures on Engineering Mathematics I and today‚Äôs we will learn Taylor‚Äôs polynomial and Taylor series.
üîπ ‚úÖ Core message preserved
üîπ Minor changes:
- Added ‚ÄúHi‚Äù
- ‚Äútoday‚Äôs we‚Äù instead of ‚Äútoday we‚Äù
- Punctuation differences only

üéôÔ∏è Sample: Exponential Function Example
üìå Original:
> The polynomial of degree 0 will simply be 1.
> If we plot this, it‚Äôs the green line through the point (0, 1).
üåÄ Whisper Output:
> So, the polynomial of degree 0 will be simply 1 and if we plot this. So, this is the green plot here of the exponential function and this polynomial of degree 0 is just a constant line. So, the straight line going through this 0 1 point.
üîπ ‚úÖ Richer phrasing from audio
üîπ Whisper added spontaneous repetitions and fillers (‚Äúso‚Äù, ‚Äúhere‚Äù)
üîπ All technical meaning retained

These examples show that Whisper Medium provides a high-fidelity transcription of spoken technical content.
In the first clip, it added a conversational ‚ÄúHi‚Äù and reordered ‚Äútoday‚Äôs we‚Äù ‚Äî a typical STT quirk, but the meaning is perfectly preserved.
In the second clip, Whisper captured additional spoken context and filler words like ‚Äúso,‚Äù which were omitted in the polished text. Still, the math-specific phrasing and structure ‚Äî like ‚Äúdegree 0 polynomial‚Äù and ‚Äúpoint (0, 1)‚Äù ‚Äî were accurate.
Overall, Whisper handled clear, structured academic English very well, even in continuous lecture format.

üìä Whisper Accuracy
üîπ Quantitative Evaluation

Semantic Similarity (cosine): 0.8882

ROUGE-1 F1 Score: 0.9116

ROUGE-L F1 Score: 0.8913

Word Error Rate (WER): 26.33%

üîç Interpretation

‚úÖ Meaning mostly preserved, despite phrasing variation

‚ö†Ô∏è Slight drop in surface-level overlap (function words, rewording)

‚ö†Ô∏è Higher WER due to longer output and added filler words


In this earlier test, Whisper Medium still performed well, but not as strongly as in the second test.
The semantic similarity score of 0.8882 indicates that the transcript largely matched the original in meaning ‚Äî even though phrasing and filler words may differ.
ROUGE scores are also strong, though slightly lower, likely because Whisper introduced additional spoken-style elements like filler words and partial repetitions that were not in the polished reference transcript.
The Word Error Rate of 26.33% is higher, but most errors were minor ‚Äî missing function words, punctuation, or changes in word order ‚Äî rather than major content issues.
This reflects Whisper‚Äôs tendency to follow real speech patterns closely, which may differ from cleaned-up transcripts.

Conclusion & Summary

STT is a mature, versatile technology
Open-source tools (Whisper, Wav2Vec) offer high quality with no cost
Cloud APIs provide convenience but incur recurring costs
Model choice depends on:
‚úÖ Accuracy
‚úÖ Cost
‚úÖ Deployment constraints
‚úÖ Privacy needs

‚úîÔ∏è Recommended:
Use Whisper for secure, offline transcription
Use cloud APIs only where real-time & scalability are critical

To wrap up:
Speech-to-text is now a reliable and accessible technology, with options for both local and cloud-based use cases. Open-source models like Whisper and Wav2Vec 2.0 offer high performance without licensing fees, making them excellent choices for internal tools or data-sensitive applications.
Cloud APIs are valuable when speed, scale, or language diversity is essential ‚Äî but they should be weighed against cost and privacy considerations.
Ultimately, the choice depends on our project‚Äôs priorities ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs minimizing cost, protecting data, supporting real-time use, or ensuring high accuracy.
Thank you.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Key Challenges

Manual note-taking is tedious and error-prone
Searchability within videos is limited
Lack of concise summaries for quick reference
Existing transcription tools are often paid or closed-source


Let‚Äôs dive into the specific problem we‚Äôre addressing. First, transcription and summarization are essential but tedious tasks if done manually ‚Äî especially for long lectures or talks. They require time, accuracy, and domain understanding ‚Äî something that‚Äôs hard to scale. Secondly, educational content often includes complex terminology, equations, and multi-speaker interactions, making accurate speech recognition even harder. Third, many existing transcription tools are cloud-based, expensive, or require constant internet ‚Äî not ideal for academic or institutional use. What we needed was a flexible, GPU-accelerated, open-source pipeline that can be used even offline, with support for different models, good accuracy, and ease of deployment. That was the challenge ‚Äî and the motivation behind this project.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Motivation
To build an open-source, end-to-end solution that enables:

Accurate transcription of video/audio files
High-quality summarization of transcripts
A web interface for ease of use by educators and students


In recent years, video content has emerged as the dominant form of communication, especially in education, conferences, and online platforms. With affordable smartphones and high-speed internet, everyone can now record and upload lectures, presentations, or tutorials. But while we have tons of valuable information in videos, extracting insights from them is still a challenge. Videos are inherently unstructured ‚Äî there‚Äôs no easy way to search through them, skim key points, or even understand the content without watching them in full. That‚Äôs where automatic transcription and summarization becomes vital ‚Äî not just for accessibility, but also for efficient knowledge retrieval and documentation. Our project aims to solve this by building a complete, end-to-end pipeline that takes in a video and outputs structured, summarized text.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Preface
This On-the-Job Training (OJT) project provided an invaluable opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge of natural language processing, deep learning, and data engineering into a real-world application. The primary objective was to build a pipeline for automatic transcription and summarization of educational and conference video content, aimed at making such content more accessible and searchable.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to Dr.¬†Dinesh Helwade for his guidance and encouragement throughout the project. It was under his initiative that this project was designed with a vision to open-source transcription and summarization tools for the benefit of educational institutions and research communities.
This project marks a critical step in combining machine learning technology with accessibility goals in education.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Project Objectives

Automate Speech-to-Text Conversion

Implement Robust Summarization

Design an Interactive Web Interface

Support Long Audio/Video Files

Ensure Local and Scalable Deployment

Improve Accessibility and Productivity


The project was driven by six main objectives:
First, to automate speech-to-text conversion using advanced models like Whisper. This automation drastically reduces the manual labor involved in transcribing lectures or meetings.
Second, to implement robust summarization techniques so users can quickly grasp the essence of lengthy content. We experimented with both traditional and transformer-based summarizers for this.
Third, to design an interactive web interface that simplifies the workflow. Whether it‚Äôs uploading files, selecting models, or downloading outputs, the interface was made intuitive and user-centric.
Fourth, to support long audio or video files, which is essential for real-world educational and conference materials that often span over an hour.
Fifth, we aimed to ensure the system could be deployed locally, especially for institutions without reliable internet. At the same time, it needed to be scalable if deployed on cloud infrastructure.
And finally, we wanted the tool to enhance accessibility and productivity ‚Äî by making academic and technical content more searchable, reviewable, and shareable.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Pipeline


This slide outlines the core pipeline that was developed during the OJT.
Step 1: The user begins by uploading an audio or video file through the web interface. We made sure the app accepts common formats like .mp4, .mp3, .wav, etc.
Step 2: If a video is uploaded, the system extracts the audio using FFmpeg and then resamples it to 16kHz mono WAV format ‚Äî which is the requirement for the transcription models.
Step 3: The audio is transcribed using either Whisper or its faster variant, Faster-Whisper. The model is loaded lazily only after the user selects it, optimizing memory usage.
Step 4: The raw transcript is cleaned and broken into manageable chunks. This ensures better summarization and avoids truncation during model inference.
Step 5: The processed chunks are summarized using the facebook/bart-large-cnn model. This step significantly reduces the size of the text while retaining the core message.
Step 6: Finally, the output is shown in the UI and the user is given options to download the transcript and summary in .txt format.

This table summarizes the strengths and limitations of some of the most widely used speech-to-text models and toolkits.
Starting with Whisper, it stands out as a balanced option ‚Äî it offers high accuracy, works offline, supports multiple languages, and is open-source. It does require a decent GPU to run efficiently, especially for long audio files or real-time use, but it‚Äôs very accessible for developers and teams with modest resources.
Wav2Vec 2.0 is another excellent option. It provides high accuracy, especially when fine-tuned on domain-specific data. However, it‚Äôs primarily trained on English datasets, so multilingual support is more limited unless you retrain it. It‚Äôs open-source and can be accessed via Hugging Face.
Google Speech-to-Text API is a commercial solution. It offers very high accuracy and supports over 100 languages. It‚Äôs excellent for real-time use cases and scales easily. However, it‚Äôs not free ‚Äî the cost is around $1.44 per hour, and it requires internet connectivity, which may raise privacy concerns in sensitive environments.
DeepSpeech was designed to be lightweight and fast, making it suitable for edge devices. That said, it has started to lag behind in terms of accuracy, especially on noisy or accented inputs, and its development has slowed down in recent years.
Kaldi is extremely powerful and flexible. It‚Äôs used in many academic and enterprise applications where low-level control is needed ‚Äî for instance, custom language models, speaker adaptation, and complex pipelines. However, it‚Äôs not beginner-friendly, and the learning curve is steep. PyKaldi can help if you want to work with it in Python.
Vosk is surprisingly effective given its small size. It offers decent accuracy, real-time performance, works fully offline, and is extremely easy to integrate ‚Äî especially on embedded systems or mobile platforms.For projects targeting Indian languages or edge devices, Vosk can be a better fit than Whisper or cloud APIs.
This slide helps us decide which model might be most appropriate depending on our project constraints ‚Äî whether we prioritize cost, offline access, multilingual support, or ease of use.
In the next slide, we‚Äôll break down the cost aspect more specifically, including free tiers and usage pricing for cloud APIs.

Tools & Technologies Used

Speech Models: Whisper(Base & Medium), Faster-Whisper

Summarization: BART (facebook/bart-large-cnn), SUMY(Luhn)

Web Interface: Streamlit
Preprocessing: FFmpeg
Programming Language: Python

Others: ONNX Runtime, Transformers


In this slide, we highlight the major tools and frameworks used in the project.
Starting with the transcription models, we used Whisper and Faster-Whisper ‚Äî both known for their accuracy and ability to handle multilingual input. Faster-Whisper offers better speed and efficiency due to its optimized inference engine.
For summarization, we used BART, specifically the facebook/bart-large-cnn model, which is well-suited for document-level abstractive summarization.
On the web interface side, the final implementation uses Streamlit because of its lightweight design and ease of development. We also explored Shiny for Python for comparison, but ultimately preferred Streamlit for its simplicity and deployment flexibility.
FFmpeg was used to handle audio extraction and conversion from video files, and waveform processing.
The entire project was built in Python, taking advantage of modern NLP libraries like Transformers and ONNX Runtime for efficient model execution.
All these tools together enabled us to create a modular, scalable, and responsive speech-to-text summarization system.

Limitations

Every machine learning project has constraints.
This section highlights key model, summarization, and deployment limitations.
Helps define boundaries for interpretation and guides future improvements.


Before diving into specific model or project-level challenges, it‚Äôs important to set context. No ML pipeline is perfect ‚Äî models come with assumptions, hardware constraints, and domain gaps.
This limitations section will help us understand where things might go wrong, or where further tuning is needed. It also points out areas where future work could yield the most benefit.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Model-Level Limitations: Whisper

Hardware Requirements: Large Whisper models need GPUs; CPU inference is slow.
Inconsistent Formatting: Output lacks punctuation and proper sentence segmentation.
Limited Domain Understanding: Struggles with mathematical or technical language.
Accent and Noise Sensitivity: Accuracy drops slightly with strong accents or noise.


Whisper performs well in general, but its size and resource demands make it difficult to run on lightweight devices. It also doesn‚Äôt always structure its output well ‚Äî which makes summarization harder. While multilingual, Whisper isn‚Äôt fine-tuned for technical subjects like mathematics, which can reduce accuracy for domain-specific lectures.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Model-Level Limitations: BART

Hallucinations: May invent information not in the transcript.
Chunking Issues: Large inputs must be split, hurting context retention.
Factual Inaccuracy: Sometimes combines unrelated ideas.
Weak with Technical Content: Fails to handle formulas or structured arguments.


BART is strong in general summarization, but prone to generating misleading or overly generic summaries. Chunk-based summarization weakens context flow, especially across topic transitions. Most critically, BART is not designed for technical domains ‚Äî it cannot preserve math expressions or logical reasoning.

title: Video/Audio Transcription and Summarization
text:
Project-Level Limitations

English-Only Evaluation: Indian languages like Hindi, Marathi not tested.
Slow Inference: Large models cause delays even with GPU.
No Real-Time Support: Pipeline is batch-based, not live.
Minimal Post-Editing: Output not cleaned for publication.


Project-level constraints also shaped results. Due to time and scope, we focused only on English data. Real-time processing was outside scope due to Whisper‚Äôs size. Summaries and transcripts were auto-generated with minimal corrections.
